answers.answer: An A1c is only one of several test for diabetes, there is also a GTT (glucose tolerance test), A1c test and Fasting test.your fasting could be high from Dawn Phenomenon DP.  DP is your body getting ready for the day and your liver dumps sugar to give you energy.  for most people there pancreas releases insulin and keep BG under 100.  For diabetics our pancreas or the insulin it makes does not work and our morning BG rises.pre diabetes isA1c of 5.7 to 6.4  isorfasting of 100 to 125orGTT test of 140 to 199Diabetes isA1c over 6.5orfasting over 140orGTT over 200I am not an MD but your numbers are up there and should be addressedFor more info  http://diabetes.niddk.nih.gov/dm/pubs/diagnosis/#3

question: In Dec and again in June my A1c was 6.2.  So my doctor says I do not have diabetes.In June I started checking my FBG. They started out around 116 and now have become over 125 every morning. Sometimes as high as 140.  But my after meal BG is usually between 125 and 145.I've been on a low carb diet since June 1st and my fasting numbers are getting worse instead of better.Does anyone know why my FBG would be so high but I still do not have spikes after eating?Is this considered diabetes?  Should I try to get my doctor to treat me for diabetes or should I be looking for another cause?
title: FBG in the range of 120 to 140
